They trade with men and tend goats above the surface, with Shamen capable of  reading fortunes. Each night they dance, sacrifice and feast on goat flesh, though Halfling, Frogling or Corvid flesh are valuable to them.

author: Joey Lindsey
description: There 7 Penlaggans here with their gut strings accidentally tied together, floating out of weapons' reach. If one unties them and lets them leave, they will tell you: Leave a blood sacrifice in hexes [[1121]] [[1521]] [[1219]] [[1323]] and [[1419]], then [[1121]] again, then return here. A demon will be summoned and have to do your bidding for a day. (Obviously they're describing topographical features and not giving pcs hex numbers, but you get the idea.)

author: Trent B
description: Forest. A single sinister but polite skeleton with a small, empty sack, a decent waterskin and a bundle of preserved mushy foods. Tirelessly roams the surface searching for children to steal away to the Lazy Witch in [[1004]].

author: Ray Colina
description: An old cleric of the Sun Peacock from the town of Axerist [[0820]] is lost in this forest. He is nearly blind from decades of staring into the sun.

author: Claytonian JP
description: One being the PCs have encountered before in their travels seems to be here. It is, of course, an impostor, and has nefarious goals. The least of which would be to shave the PCs in their sleep.

author: Trent B
description: Forest with some wild cherries and 3 Elk. Also various fungus: If chosen randomly D6: 1-3 Edible. 4-5 Poisonous. 6 Turn eater into a myconid/fungusman in D6 days (con save)

author: Trent B
description: SPOREGORGON (Settlement) Fen containing the beginnings of a mossy, fragrant Fungusman hamlet, leading south to an algae filled lake. The Fungusmen will trade algal salves/potions for unusual organic materials. If murdered upon, their bobbly fungus head explodes into spores that turn nearby humanoids into fungusmen in D6 days (con/breath save).

author: Claytonian JP
description: Old Kappas on an expedition to catch the giant fish in [[1226]]. Will give kappa hooch to those that help them hunt and advise against consorting with minstrels.

author: Trent B
description: Swamp, but with Travelling Minstrels! Except actually Wererats. Currently composing a ballad about how thieving and villainous the Minstrels from [[0527]] are. Presently tracking the Minstrels to murder and supplant them.

author: Trent B
description: ZAK MADRAS (Settlement) Dwarves! They don't like you, but will let you stay just inside their gate, under guard, overnight for 20gp each.

author: Claytonian JP
description: There is a doorway here. It is only visible from the front and cannot be touched from behind. If the PCs open it, they will find themselves entering into a dungeon that the DM may make up or just pull from his bookshelf.

author: Trent B
description: A small collection of Corvid (Cunning little Crowmen) Alchemists and Tinkers live in treetop laboratories on the mountainside, crafting firearms, chemicals and potions with their dexterous talons. Will trade for unusual substances or rare monster parts. Their telescopic observatories command a view 8 hexes to the east, south and west, and to the Dracolisk's Mountain Lair in 14 13.

author: Claytonian JP
description: The armadas of two tribes meet here in a decisive battle for who will be the true empress of the shadow nation.

author: Trent B
description: A badly damage, burning ship flees the battle in [[1404]] with what is left of its crew. It is pursued by 12 racist pirates in a small, fast vessel.

author: Ray Colina
description: A racist pirate is marooned on this island for his lame jokes and terrible B.O. He's actually an apt, if bloodthirsty, sailor with sturdy morale.

author: Trent B
description: A morbidly fat lady from a settlement in [[1809]], collapsed, sweaty and exhausted, by a rock in the forest. She has left her husband and decided to move to Wormwallow in [[1309]]. She is too ill and fatigued to make it alone and has stolen 275GP of her ex husbands money.

author: Random Wizard
description: A powerful wizard sits here before three paths into the woods, warning the adventurers that an ogre lurks down one of the paths, and a great treasure resides down another. No matter which path the adventurers take, they will encounter the Ogre because the wizard uses teleport to put the Ogre on their path since the Ogre and wizard work together to rob adventurers of their treasure.

author: Joey Lindsey
description: The invisible Tower of the Ashen Hand - an assassin training cult. The song and dance to make the tower visible can be pieced together from info from the Dwarves in [[1401]] and Corvid in [[1403]]. The Ashen Hand are happy to give a tour of their training facility to anyone knowing the song and dance, believing them to be wealthy clients.

author: Trent B
description: Swamp and mire, with small, uncommon patches of wildflowers emerging. The wildflowers seed into gemlike pods, worth 10 GP each. Undead Froglings, Humans and Apes stalk the murk for the flesh and brains of conscious beings.

author: Casey Garske
description: An unholy pit is filled with the desecrated holy symbols  of a forgotten pantheon of gods and also 1d4+2 manticores.

author: Trent B
description: Sharp, rocky hills rise up to the base of the Dracolisk's mountain in [[1413]]. Chasms occasionally split the earth, dropping into the underground ruins of the Black Marble city where foul things creep.

author: Trent B
description: The mountaintop ruin of a black marble city that once sprawled from [[1311]] to [[1616]] is now the home an ancient dracolisk.

author: Joey Lindsey
description: An ancient Maintenance Construct endlessly roams the black marble city, seeking "Masters" to "Repair". If invited to help an injured person, it will try to paralyze any healthy people present with a shock attack and extract their "useful parts" to "repair" the injured person.

author: Joey Lindsey
description: The dump of the ancient marble city appears stable, but could collapse when weight is put upon it. Gasses from rotting matter have caused eternal underground fires here.

author: Trent B
description: A single corvid from [[1403]], with a bodyguard of 2 humans, 2 froglings and an elf, camp in a valley.The corvid searches the mountains for a way into the black marble city.

author: Joey Lindsey
description: A grassy field with occasional bushes. Hyper gnomes and faeries run from spot to spot, and a plume of oddly colored mist emerges from a hole in the ground, drifting over the field and into the South.

author: Ray Colina
description: The woods here are idyllic. Should the party camp overnight they gain +2 hp. Camping a second night triggers a wandering monster roll.

author: Trent B
description: Lovely woods with fruit and deer. 9 Wolves, two are pregnant.

author: Ray Colina
description: From time to time a great tumult of air bubbles erupts from the depths here endangering boats present. An air elemental is bound at the lake's bottom.

author: M Nicksic
description: At the bottom of the lake lies a cargo container that fell off the space capsule which crashed in 01 21. It is filled with fleshy sacs of viscous goo that the squishy aliens use as nourishment. 1 sac contains enough goo to sustain a human for a week.

author: Ray Colina
description: The trees here make excellent furniture. The wood cutters here want booze. One asks if they'd deliver to Chiang, in [[DAMNATION]] [[0816]], the news that his brother was eaten by a giant weasel.

author: Ray Colina
description: The party sees a steady plume of smoke in the distance.  If they investigate, they find the collapsing remains of burning wicker man. There is no sign of who did this, but by examining the tracks a ranger can determine they did it to themselves.

author: Ray Colina
description: The trees here are Sequoia massive. In the hollow of a particularly massive tree, the giant weasel mention in [[1422]] makes its lair. Under a pile of bones in its warren is a 500 gp emerald.

author: Claytonian JP
description: A forest of statues, who are the victims of a gorgon/medusa/whatevs that has wandered to another hex.... They will organize themselves into an unruly mercenary war-band under the guidance of a lvl 10 cleric that is among them, should they come back to flesh en masse, within a day.

author: Ray Colina
description: A clearing housing three small farms. There is neither people or livestock here as they are the sacrifices found in [[1423]]. A demodand lurks in the basement of the largest farmhouse.

author: Claytonian JP
description: A settlement unstuck in time that presents a different aspect and size depending on which direction the party approaches it from. -300 years hamlet in the South and +100 more years from there going clockwise (SE is +400 years advanced metropolis).

author: Zak Smith
description: Goblins looking for the entrance to their home in the dungeon at [[1402]] after having been blinded by the dwarves in [[1401]].

author: M Nicksic
description: The corvid alchemists from [[1403]] have a salt refining operation here. Vast evaporation ponds are tended/guarded by massive clockwork automatons. If asked nicely, the corvids will sell you some of the paste they use to protect the automatons from corrosion.

author: Jacob Hurst
description: Wreck of "The Jolly Daggers" (Merchant ship - spice/fabric) on a reef of bio-luminescent coral. Now inhabited by a sea hag seeking three feathers from a purple bird only found in the ruins of the Black Marble City.

author: Claytonian JP
description: A procession of warrior-nobles is on an island or shore here enjoying a seasonal sight. Cherry tree petals falling, moon viewing, or autumnal leaves, perhaps.

author: Jacob Hurst
description: A fleet of at least 100 ghostly fishing ships sails these waters each night, fading away at dawn. On nights of the full moon and new moon these vessels release hundreds of translucent, glowing paper lanterns.

author: Justin Howe
description: A group of sahuagin outcasts patrols these waters. They serve the sea-hag in [[1503]].

author: Zak Smith
description: The dozen towers jutting from the water here ( left over from when this area was a fortified harbor ) are now home to drow pirates. A mile-long network of spider webs stretches between them over the water.

author: C. W. Marshall
description: When the tides rose last century, the wharf and the seaside village of Sailor's Rest was submerged. It now can be seen at low tide, a few feet below the surface. Some vessels get reefed in the branches of the old Elm.

author: Duncan Young
description: the shoreline is littered with coins that have washed up - all bearing the face and mark of Emperor Titian the Red, and all of them fake. Aquatic and burrowing variants of rust monsters plague the region

author: Zak Smith
description: ORTHRIST This sprawling port city, known for its red lanterns, began as a colossal fortress that used to guard the bay during the Bleak Wars. Built and sealed on many levels and in many ways to protect from centuries of unpredictable weather, the southern outskirts of the city merge imperceptibly with half-buried ruins to the south.

author: Niles Calder
description: a wizard's tower sits here unfinished. The wizard and his dwarven workers are in dispute after someone spilled beer on the blueprints and now the scale is all off. Resolving the dispute one way or another will make the PCs powerful friends and enemies.

author: M Nicksic
description: Inside a fairy ring, an anthropomorphic squirrel (wearing a very nice hat in a very old style) dances an endless jig. Destroying the circle will free him, but his memories of life as a cruel wizard are unreliable at best as he has gone quite mad over the centuries. He has a 1% chance of remembering something useful about the Black Marble City.

author: Niles Calder
description: Somewhere in this forest lies the entrance to the Caverns of Unending Sorrows.

author: Zak Smith
description: A thief is trapped here, webbed months ago by the capricious wizard in [[1509]] on the road to Orthrist [[1508]]. He knows the dracolisk's true name (Vorax) and that it is immune to magic unless the caster uses the name.

author: Anthony Stiller
description: An old crone is driving what appears to be a gypsy caravan along a rutted road however the caravan is actually sentient (having escaped from the Golem Factory at [[0814]]) and the crone is its slave. If attacked the wagon transforms into a powerful wood golem. The golem's power source is a portal to the Outer Realms, deep within its belly.

author: Zak Smith
description: A small (rabbit-sized) blindheim lurks in the glossy black ruins here. It has collected 6500 gp worth of gems for reasons unknown.

author: Niles Calder
description: There is a path through these mountains marked by cairns. One of these is made of unfinished black marble blocks. Beneath it is buried a large clay pot containing a golden scroll that points to the locations of "great treasures" once translated.

author: Zak Smith
description: Three linked, rooklike and geometric towers here are completely infested with crawling claws. Whether this is due to the capricious magic of the former ancient inhabitants or the dracolisk is unknown.

author: Duncan Young
description: This regions is very prone to earthquakes and mudslides, which have been known to reveal several buried tombs of a lost winged, eagle-headed humanoid tribe. These people were in fact lycanthropes, and their descendants guard their treasures jealously.

author: Zak Smith
description: The southernmost marble watchtower is now the haunt of goblin treasure-hunters seeking their fortune in the ruins of the black city. They are served by a pack of 6 berserk, drugged babboons dyed lurid colors.

author: Zak Smith
description: A knight of a kingdom to the east seeks to prevent the marriage of one of the ogre mages [[1006]] to a princess of a rival kingdom [[1201]] as it will cement a powerful alliance against his liege.

author: Duncan Young
description: Freddegar, the major domo to Lord Frast in [[NINE NEERING]] [[1127]] is a normally respectable man, but with a few drinks in him at night, swears blind that he was caught in a hailstorm of fist-sized diamonds dropping from the sky whilst travelling in this region

author: Zak Smith
description: A ranger has been tracking something for three days that murdered an entire village. The tracks seem to warp and change every few miles.

author: Anthony Stiller
description: Deliberately buried underneath a collapsed mill are 3 small, gold ingots each stamped with an elven rune and spattered with blood.  The ingots are each cursed and make the location of the bearer known to a secret organisation of witch hunters who wield black powder weapons.

author: Zak Smith
description: AZEL EIRE (settlement) Although it looks like six miles of forest connecting the lake at [[1621]] to the lake at [[1424]], the greenery actually grows on a vast and aging stone platform built over a river connecting the two lakes. The people of Azel Eire catch blind fish using cylindrical cages they lower through holes in the false ground.

author: Claytonian JP
description: Some ruins are to be found here. Any who present themselves in front of an ancient dais will be judged, punished and/or rewarded by a forgotten entity of supreme justice.

author: Zak Smith
description: A long-armed hobgoblin whose touch causes madness lives in a tall hedge maze. Likely responsible for the wicker man in [[1423]].

author: Claytonian JP
description: A small cabin in the woods. A variety of weapons are within, and one is actually magical, but anyone who spends the night will meet their doom when the undying man that once owned them comes back.

author: Niles Calder
description: A herd of 96 Wild Cattle roam this hex.

author: Reece Carter
description: swamp goblins live here, they are a amalgamation of spiders and goblins (think centaur), they attack from webs that they have spun in an ambush like attack. Their web sack (where the web comes from) it is rumored to be worth a bit of money

author: Zak Smith
description: This house-of-cards-like henge is actually an ancient sun calendar built in the earliest years of the earth by the Callow Men. The command words for various ancient locks and wards all over the map--from the black marble city to the dungeons to the ruins beneath the sea, can be discovered if one "reads" the moonlight filtering through the structure on the night corresponding numerically to the geomantic code of the ancients.

author: Niles Calder
description: A Giant Leech can be found here. Although it can be encountered anywhere within the swamp, along with its offspring, it spends most of it's time (80%) within this hex.

author: Niles Calder
description: The half sunk wreck of a merchantman wallows in the sea here. Much of its cargo has spoiled due to being submerged but 2d4x1000 GP can be recovered by anyone prepared to brave the drowned hold and crew (7 undead crewmen, treat as Wights).

author: Zak Smith
description: A 3 foot tall statue of Naxxice of the Fathoms sits on a tiny island. Extra arms have been added, his feet have been chiseled into hooves and the head has been replaced with the head of Est Mourn, God of Shipwrecks.

author: Reece Carter
description: its said that sirens are very prevalent in this area, so much so that pirates and the superstitious stear clear of this whole area

author: Michael Currie
description: Several sargasso rafts are home to small timid mer-apes who will exchange lewd scrimshaw for alcohol or drugs.

author: M Nicksic
description: d8 mimics masquerading as floating crates.

author: Stuart Marshall
description: Cave.  Contains giant rats and 2000 cp.

author: Claytonian JP
description: An earth mote with a keep floats tantalizingly just 30 feet above sea level here. The keep is only the abode of monsters these days.

author: Zak Smith
description: the more secluded end of the city of [[ORTHRIST]] sprawl: Nil Zerise experiments with telescopes, Orbin Wayward attempts to piece together the area's true geography and history using fragmentary maps from passing travelers, Volve Spinnaker presides over the city's lurid madhouse.

author: Niles Calder
description: Five young magic users, apprentices of the Wizard in [[1509]], are camping here drinking beer and 'fixing the world'. The four men are completely enamoured with the solitary woman in their company and believe themselves romantic rivals for her affections. She has no feelings for any of her companions beyond camaraderie and would be upset to learn of their intentions.

author: Zak Smith
description: A well here is full of poison toads, beneath them is a tunnel leading to a secret door behind the throne room in the Caverns of Unending Sorrow under [[1511]].

author: Zak Smith
description: An elegant carriage sent to fetch the woman in [[1609]] and bring her to meet her new husband--one of the brothers in [[1006]]. Most of the wedding party (including the guards) have been slain by goblins during the journey and the driver and bride's father (the only survivors) will handsomely reward anyone willing to keep them safe for the rest of their trip. The father knows of the monstrous nature of the would-be husband but has kept it a secret from everyone, including the bride, in order to more easily secure a powerful ally.

author: Zak Smith
description: Bandits (3 Rot Goblins, 2 White Goblins, 3 Red goblins, 1 hyena) ambush those on the road to or from Orthrist ( [[1508]] , [[1608]] ) by dropping down from above. Their lair, a ramshackle wooden complex in a tangle of huge black trees, contains 3600gp and a map to the burial mounds in 11 11 along with scribbled theories (50% correct) on how to avoid the traps.

author: Claytonian JP
description: In hill-houses, a tribe of halflings with great facial hair. They are hopeful that their favored son who went off towards the west to seek his fortune with a band of adventurers is fairing well (see  [[0113]]).

author: M Nicksic
description: A halfling sells "100% Authentic Maps of the City of Black Marble" for 100gp from a small hut by the side of the road. Not only are the maps wholly inaccurate, they are enchanted to betray the location of the bearer to the halfling's three assassin partners.

author: Zak Smith
description: The easternmost towers of the ruined black marble city stand in a pentagon around a triangular pool filled with unnaturally blue water. Two wizards, Orlast and Kraal, bitter rivals, wander amidst the tower libraries, seeking ancient secrets while avoiding both each other and the dracolisk [[1413]].

author: Wayne Snyder
description: Deep in this lush woodland a giant forest spirit dwells in a great hollow tree filled with soft mosses and frolicing butterflies. It is a good neighbor and can use it's mighty roar to summon a twelve legged cat bus at will.

author: Ray Colina
description: Near a decapitated marble statue of Cacodemon, a Corvid battles with two of the emaciated goat-headed humanoids from [[CLOVECRUSHED]] [[1320]]. The Cacodemons head lies nearby, in the forest undergrowth. Anyone who replaces the head on the statue is immediately teleported before a simailar statue in the beer cellar of [[FELLMOUNT ABBEY]] [[0902]].

author: Jensan Thuresson
description: Petrified druid hugging a tree

author: Matt Maranda
description: A pack of wolves have been slaughtered here, but there are no tracks other than wolf spore. It appears that whatever did this was over 8' tall had a beak and slashing claws.

author: Matt Maranda
description: This large lake is perfectly flat, ripples only appear when an object forcefully agitates its surface.

author: M Nicksic
description: A nearly-finished canal stretches from the seashore at [[1722]] towards the lake at [[1620]]. Tracks and other evidence at the work site suggests that the workers abandoned the project and walked into the eerily calm lake en masse. Tools lay where they were dropped, free for the taking - they are serviceable, but not worth much.

author: Ray Colina
description: A hunting party of 6 emaciated goat-headed men has set up a lakeside camp. They are smoking Frogling legs in a makeshift oven of piled rocks.

author: Ray Colina
description: A decapitated marble of a statue of Cacodemon identical to the one in [[1617]], overlooks the lake here, Froglings, wounded from their battle with the emaciated goat-headed humanoids [[1622]], hide in the water, but will warn any who attempt to replace the demon head. Anyone who proceeds anyway is immediately teleported before a similar statue in the gardens of the PALACE OF 1OOO TERRACES [[0611]].

author: Peter Seckler
description: A hidden grove here contains a lair of brightly-colored giant trap-door spiders. They have an unusual coloration- bright magenta bands on their legs.

author: Peter Seckler
description: a creek winds its way through here, and there is a spring with fresh drinkable water.

author: Peter Seckler
description: A humanoid rabbit (known as 'Paddy Cottontail')  lives in a quaint burrow here and has a small farming plot on the side of the hill. He is cautious but friendly, and happens to be a skilled musician with the lyre. If threatened he knows some basic magic- enough to cast a sleep and a charm spell.  He doesn't like to fight.

author: Ray Colina
description: The rocky island that juts up from the lake here has a decapitated marble statue of a Cacodemon, anyone who replaces the head is immediately teleported to castle ruins in [[0908]]. If all three heads are ever restored [[1623]], [[1617]], then any whom placed the heads are immediately teleported before Azi the Harmer, Cacodemon Prince. Azi gives each of them a magic item and binds them into his service for a year and a day.

author: Bennet Akkerman
description: On these grasslands there is a large stone disk covering a hole in the ground, below there's a cave with white plants and a trident lodged in a black stone shaped like an heart. The trident is holy and can only be wielded by those pure of heart, but it can only pulled loose by black hearted creatures.

author: David Brawley
description: This hilly area next to the calm waters of [[1703]] is home to the small fishing and farming village of Corwin. At the center of the village stands a green and gold obelisk that causes those who spend time near it to want to settle in the village and lead a peaceful life.

author: Reece Carter
description: the shore along here is really calm, like so calm that its weird

author: Ray Colina
description: A amongst crumbling the crumbling ruins of the hilly island here, is a working fountain in perfect repair. Any who drink from it may never leave the island. The island's current residents, 2 racist pirates, a halfling assassin and a cleric of the Sun Peacock bitterly try to trick others into drinking.

author: Bennet Akkerman
description: If a boat get's caught in the maelstrom here, it will transport the vessel in a 1d6 direction and 1d6 hexes away, there's a 3% chance a vessel will be instead transported to [[0401]] or [[2016]]. The vessel will be damaged on arrival and any crewmembers that could hang on will get [hexes transported]d6 damage (max 8d6).

author: Reece Carter
description: a large (giant sized) eel lives in this area, it preys upon various animal species that live in the brackish waters (the edge it shares with [[1707]]). Tall tales are spun about this eel in various fishermans pubs, some of those tales are true

author: Ray Colina
description: Hanging from one of the many hemlock trees growing in this swamp is an iridescent multicolored holy symbol of the Sun Peacock. Any cleric can use the holy symbol, turning undead at +2 levels, however, they become increasingly obsessed with fashion, eventually spending 75% of all wealth on increasingly elaborate and expensive clothes to complement the holy symbol.

author: Random Wizard
description: Swamp gas and 2d12 zombies do not mix.

author: M Nicksic
description: Those too poor to live within Orthrist proper make their homes here, building stilted houses over the brackish water. There is a thriving trade in medicinal leeches.

author: Matt Maranda
description: A pack of wereboars have become the dominant force in these woods They are debating granting their "gift" to the villagers of [[1708]]. They fear the lake in [[1710]] and do not go near it.

author: Reece Carter
description: the waters of this lake are cursed and evil, drinking from it make you thirsty-er, the fish and other various animals that live it in are poisonous to eat. There is a small island in the very center of the lake where everything is good. Traveling to this small island is one of the most perilous things that you could do

author: Casey Garske
description: They call this the Owlbear Forest because this forest is FULL of owlbears. All random encounters in this hex will be owlbears.

author: Ed Hackett
description: Rotted dryad grove. Poisoned by underground runoff from the cursed lake to the north.

author: Joey Lindsey
description: A man and his cat have been hung poorly from a tree. Their necks are broken, but they are alive and starving due to the rope being poorly tied. They know which spots in the area are popular for bandits and monsters to attack, and about the fountain in [[1704]].

author: Claytonian JP
description: That cat is a witch. She's really not so bad, once you get to know her. EDIT: not saying it's a witch, sometimes a cat is a cat?

author: Ray Colina
description: Sujay, an illusionist, has made is home in a ruined castle along a small bay. He has in his service thirty pirates, their ship, and two charmed owlbears from [[1711]].  A fresco in one of the crumbling towers depicts the nearby coastline and marks the locations of the Cacodemon statues in [[1617]], [[1623]] and [[1627]].

author: Joey Lindsey
description: The older couple with a cabin near the shore have no interest in the occasional coin or gem that washes up from the East. Further inland, several gelatinous cubes wander, looking for a way back underground.

author: Matt Maranda
description: A group of Witch-hunters an offshoot of the Sun Peacock's clergy patrol this land. Overzealous, they have found several demons and witches. They left the cat & her familiar on the tree in [[1713]] and are searching for holy woods to burn them with.

author: M Nicksic
description: This area was largely deforested in order to aid extraction of the enchanted clay below. The boowtown that grew up around this industry was abandoned when the clay-golem-bubble burst after the War, and the buildings are slowly sinking into the mud. Any rainfall makes this entire hex difficult terrain for a week afterwards.

author: Gus L
description: Recent Battlefield between two local tribes.  Scattered bodies looted of weapons and valuables represent the losers (The Forest People) while a nearby cairne contains the honored dead of the victorious hill people.  Generally a reeking and depressing mess.  Carrion birds can be seen from miles off.

author: Ray Colina
description: The Citadel of Bone, so named because its blocks are carved from the petrified bones of titans. The Warlord Rastazar lives here with 50 brigand henchman. Rastazar wears a cursed pig-faced warmask which allows him to see in the dark but may be only removed in death, forcing him to take all nourishment through a straw.

author: Ray Colina
description: GRIGLAZZ a slovenly village of pig-faced orc-pirates who owe fealty to Rastazar in [[1718]]. They are led by Grimslag, Captain of the Maslayer, an orc fighter of great strength (18) and ample girth.

author: Steve Sigety
description: A pack of blink dogs will suddenly surround and follow travellers in the woods, barking, jumping and carrying sticks to play fetch. Any attempts to be stealthy are foiled by the attention.

author: Ed Hackett
description: A single stone monument to an ancient battle fought in the fields here.

author: Ray Colina
description: Mottled blue crab warriors spawning grounds. The crab warriors attempt to drive off all who enter these waters.

author: Zak Smith
description: Remains of a battle weeks ago between a witch hunter and a chaos warband on a half-mile bridge linking parts of [[1724]] and [[1623]]. The gore and blasphemy on display have thus far scared off looters, many of the emaciated goatmen in the area ([[1320]], [[1617]], [[1622]] ) are remnants of this once-proud warband. The dead witch hunter's notes have maps showing the last known locations of all the witches on the hexmap ([[0121]], [[0715]], [[1808]], [[1909]], [[1910]], [[1713]] has a question mark, and the coven in [[1109]] which includes the witches in [[1014]], [[1026]], and [[1004]] and [[1106]] -- who used to live together in [[0103]] ).

author: Shaine Edwards
description: A badly wounded scribe is being cared for by a small, clairvoyant girl. A tiny pair of goat horns sprout from her forehead.

author: Ed Hackett
description: A renowned elven swordsman keeps a cabin here. He no longer takes students.

author: Ray Colina
description: The iron wood trees here are very difficult to work but make strong hulls. Pig-faced orc pirates from [[GRIGLAZZ]] [[1718]] attempt build a ship, but the combination of laziness and poor tools makes for little progress.

author: Matt Maranda
description: Here there is an apple orchard with a well before it and farm house to the side. The farmer asks for 4cp per peck any who take without paying are cursed by him.

author: Ray Colina
description: The Oak Daughter, a swanmay lives here in an old cabin by the water. She is the wife of the wizard Orlast [[1615]], but has little interest in libraries.

author: Joshua Macy
description: Hippogriff's nest.  Mother and 1d4 foals.

author: Matt Maranda
description: A dwarf and three halfling merchants are picking through shipwreck remains washed ashore. Their orcish servants wait chained and ready to pull two surviving carts. If questioned they reveal they are from a shipping town in the mountains of [[2001]] and were returning from trading with alchemists in [[1502]].

author: Gus L
description: The Northern half of the Trial of the Long Causeway, a shattered bridge of monumental reddish stone that leads from [[1802]] to [[1805]].  The bridge and it's towers are more intact here than to the South, but it's stonework is deceptively solid looking and the slick stones crumble into the frothing sea below with ease.

author: Zak Smith
description: Bored Queen Morgause and her devoted sons search a nameless island for blue salamanders. She knows impaling one and eating its lungs grants you the ability to breathe water. The witch hunter [[1723]], is aware of her activities but feared to name her for political reasons.

author: Mike Evans
description: A large whirlpool that rotates counter clockwise.  Down at the bottom is a gigantic red eye.

author: Gus L
description: The Southern half of the Trial of the Long Causeway, a shattered bridge of monumental stone that leads from [[1802]] to [[1805]].  Here there are only jagged pillars and debris from the fallen bridge that present a menace to navigation, and a said to be the home of hideous flesh eating "mermaids".

author: Gus L
description: The Isle of Judgment was once a temple prison to a god of hopelessness and punishment. The the ruins of a large ornate complex of layered stone tiers rises dolorously from a hardwood forest where the degenerate descendant prisoners still venerate a lost god with croaking subhumans chants.

author: Joshua Macy
description: Animals entering this hex gradually become intelligent and capable of speech within 1d4 hours; effect persists for 1d4 hours after leaving the hex.  It doesn't change their nature (e.g. they don't build cities or wear clothes).

author: Joey Lindsey
description: A merchant from [[WORMWALLOW]] [[1309]] is marooned here with a large store of food and many [[MULK]] glasswares. She will lament trading away her 3 crocodiles to any who will listen. She was cast off the vessel in [[1601]] for inciting mutiny before it was wrecked by the sirens in [[1603]].

author: Matthew Burack
description: A navy frigate has subdued a pirate vessel but sustained heavy losses in the battle. The pirates are about to be hung from the yardarm while their plunder is being confiscated, then the ship will be scuttled.

author: Joey Lindsey
description: Twelve White Elves from [[SCREEYAL]] [[0112]] riding dinosaurs. Lost and trying to find the Golem Factory in [[0814]]. They are out of supplies and have been foraging and killing other travelers for food.

author: Zak Smith
description: A blood trail leads down a ferret hole to a long, ancient vertical shaft library. Many books but even more snakes (some now eating the ferret). Properly read, the snakes can reveal the geomantic code to reading the ruins in [[1527]].

author: David Brawley
description: This boggy forest is home to a hobbled witch living in a cottage. The mushrooms growing around the cottage are psychedelic and talkative.

author: Ray Colina
description: The Weird Black Plinths of Mount Yarling are said to provide confusing but prophetic dreams to those who dare to sleep amongst them. The Mount is rumored to be the lair of a vampire, but the more immediate danger comes from Witch-Hunters who watch the area, convinced that consulting the dream stones here is tantamount to trafficking with demons.

author: Mike Evans
description: Hut with lonely old man inside.  He bores you with stories from his life.  Make a save or fall asleep for 1d6 years from boredom.

author: Chris Blauwkamp
description: The southern edge of this hex ends in sharp cliffs. The wind as it blows throw the nooks and crannies sounds like a mournful version of the Harlem Globetrotters theme.

author: Martin Bay Thomsen
description: Giant Sea Cucumbers. If brought to the surface they shrivel and harden, their skin makes for excellent armor.

author: Joey Lindsey
description: The tide and coastal shape causes detritus to wash up and get stuck in this stinky bog. Crocodiles and hippopotamuses live in an uneasy truce.

author: Gus L
description: The seas here are unremarkable, but there is excellent fishing and the shallow coastal waters contain edible sea urchin colonies.

author: Gus L
description: Mysterious spheres of black tar and slicks of oil float on the surface of these teeming waters.  The oil and tar is the product of a natural deep sea deposit that is farmed by listless earth elementals.

author: Martin Bay Thomsen
description: Murderous pixie couple killing time by drowning frogs in a small pond. One wears a magic ring as a waistband.

author: Zak Smith
description: Entering a gazebo here (dwarf scaled) brings you out dwarf sized into an identical wood with a small house (halfling scale) and entering the halfling house brings you out halfling sized into an identical wood with a dog house, entering the dog house brings you out 2' tall into an identical wood containing a bird cage, entering the bird cage leads you (now bird sized) to a court of Unseelie faerie folk (home of the pixies in 18 17 ), currently negotiating an alliance with a lizard representing a hobgoblin from the warband at Griglazz ( 17 19 ).

author: Ray Colina
description: The waters of DOLDRUM BAY are very deep and very still. Ships without oars who enter the inviting looking bay will find themselves adrift for 1d4 days trying to catch a rare breeze, even dropping anchor is difficult do the water's depth. White Elves from [[SCREEYAL]] [[0112]] in Viking ships, lie in wait.

author: Matt Maranda
description: Treants live in this wood.

author: Zak Smith
description: EELVAST--this fortified trading settlement was built in the wreck of a massive zoo/slave ship from Yoon Suin. While most of the current inhabitants are descended from human or Drownesian pirates, the fierce mottled blue crab warriors,  [[1722]], the wild animals in [[1920]], the leech-headed halflings [[1220]] and many other species not native to the Hexenbracken originated here.

author: David Brawley
description: Giant hermit crabs

author: James Clark
description: Houseboat anchored one mile off shore & occupied by a family of five greys (short, lean build with hairless, grey-skinned bodies;  big heads & eyes; small mouths, no external noses or ears)  .  They're on the lamb from witch hunters for some past misunderstanding. They keep a low profile, but are willing to trade fish and pearls for copper and gold.

author: James Clark
description: large pearl bed on sandy floor, 100' down.  giant pikes (the kind with gills and fins).

author: Random Wizard
description: A travelling merchant barge named Mentzer's Menagerie plods along the shore here. The head merchant is happy to answer questions about what lies along the eastern coast provided the questioner is willing to buy some bauble at a reasonable price.

author: Stuart Marshall
description: Tribespeople, live on rafts, dive for pearls --- intelligent giant mutant crustaceans prey on them

author: Zak Smith
description: Nothing lives about these beaches but limpets and kelp, a few curiously furtive terns which survive for the most part by eating one another’s eggs, and in season a handful of deformed seals. -M John Harrison, Viriconium

author: Zak Smith
description: The black swans in the large pond here are victims of the farmer's curse [[1727]] which separates bodies (you've seen the undead around here right?) from souls (these black swans) at death. Some have attempted to court The Oak Daughter [[1728]] with mixed success.

author: David Brawley
description: A band of Vistani is traveling toward the greys in [[1822]] to trade for pearls.

author: Zak Smith
description: Port Of Idiots-- like the morons in [[1101]], these unfortunates have been made stupid by the plinth in [[0913]]. Forever asking to trade for weevils while fondling spotted chicken eggs, they sorely test the composure of the kind people of Corwin [[1702]].

author: Martin Bay Thomsen
description: Band of orcs entertaining themselves by launching captured morons from [[1901]] out in the ocean from the beach with a large catapult.

author: Ray Colina
description: Lady Yavika the self-stiyed merchant queen and occasional pirate, plies these waters in her lavender-sailed, three masted sloop, the Primrose Princess. Beleg, her dour white elf lover, and skipper, never far from her side.

author: Jason Sholtis
description: Sorcerer's Guild vessel makes bee-line for [[1901]], loaded to the gills with new and experimental products to be given extensive trials among the idiot population.

author: Zak Smith
description: A group of hyperintelligent crows [[1805]] tricked the crew of this foundering vessel into destroying the idol of the Isle of Judgment (also [[1805]]). They are now cursed to roam the area until they meet the god of forgotten judgment once more  [[1522]].

author: Ray Colina
description: Sea Dogs, play and romp in these waters and sun themselves along the coasts and islets. Their incessant barking can be wearing on the nerves.

author: Ray Colina
description: Three angry idiots endlessly bicker and complain about and at the barking sea dogs.  Luck and the current brought them here after being catapulted into the ocean by the orcs in [[1902]], but now they are either too stupid or stubborn to leave.

author: Reece Carter
description: cursed elves live here, they have been cursed by a witch to take on the aperance of that which they cherish most, which for these guys are the trees, flowers, and other plants. They have a damage reduction of 1-2 to everything (except axes and fire), and will react violently to anyone who brings an axe into their hex

author: Jason Sholtis
description: Conclave of naked forest hippies spend their careless days in meditation, zero-impact hunting and gathering, procreating abundantly and gratefully donating many offspring to Yeegra the vernal witch, who abides alone in a grand tree-mansion suspended in the canopy.

author: Zak Smith
description: A tower barely emerging from the mist and branches at the foothills of [[1911]] is home to Glisten Wrakk, a rain witch. She is the third part of the coven formed by Yeegra [[1909]] and the nameless hobbled witch in [[1809]] and considers herself the brains of the operation.

author: Reece Carter
description: the mountains and hills in this area are warped by the magic of the witches, they dont really seem to follow any logic patern. Walking across this hex will take both a short amount of time and a really really long time. Any random encounter on this hex magical in nature and twisted by these magics

author: Zak Smith
description: A group of clowns from the Vollen Veen merchant kingdoms sent to perform at the wedding of one of the ogre magi in [[1006]]. They are lost.

author: Ray Colina
description: This mossy forest smells of cabbage and the air swims with countless swarming gnats, at night, an enormity of cricket song. In the hollow of venerable old oak, Yoka the Wad, a tiny goblin witch and her grig and pixie companions have made their coven.

author: Zak Smith
description: Rot Goblins with harpoons and grappling hooks hunt giant spiny puffer fish to seal and use as sea-balloons.

author: Jason Sholtis
description: Unsubstantiated rumors tell of Yithrilae, domed city of the jelly-men, just visible deep below the waves. Within the dome the jellies diligently labor at literature, music and art, all of which inspire terror and nausea in human-types. Enslaved glassblowers from [[MULK]] sneak out pleas for rescue in exquisitely crafted bottles.

author: Zak Smith
description: A toad in the water here can talk and knows the way to the Unseelie Court [[1818]]. It also claims to know the way to a hidden treasure on the island at [[2011]] and will tell the PCs in exchange for killing the hobgoblin of Griglazz

author: Zak Smith
description: An old tower rising from the water here has been converted into a tavern, The Nivling Clasp, known for its stewed bream and blistered eggs. Though inhabited by the usual shifting cast of reavers, slavers and mutilated adventurers it is widely regarded by most humans as the safest place in the Hexenbracken.

author: Steve Sigety
description: A boat is in danger of capsizing as fishermen fight an enormous undead shark caught in their nets (turn as a Wraith).

author: Reece Carter
description: fishing here is so easy that they almost just jump onto the boat, +4 to any survival checks or fishing checks

author: Reece Carter
description: lions, tigers, and bears

author: Reece Carter
description: the water here has a more greenish hue to it then anywhere else. This is because of the soul-stones trapped at the bottom of the ocean.

author: Zak Smith
description: The worst poet in New Feierland was stuffed in a cage with 300 days rations, strapped into a rowboat and shoved into the sea. After 230 days, he's fetched up here--he has seen much.

author: Reece Carter
description: a wizard riding on thay back of a giant tortoise, this wizard is responsible for what is happening in [[1922]].

author: Reece Carter
description: traveling merchant vessels, they are happy to trade with the PCs and are very good at getting the bettee deal. They trade goods for goods and infomation for memories (this is particularly hazardous for a spell caster)

author: Zak Smith
description: Deep beneath the water here is the shattered and  gargantuan body of a long dead city-tortoise. It contains the entrance to a vast ruined subsea complex of polished, half-flooded tunnels choked with slime inhabited by mind flayers and ambulatory, amphibious ixitachitil dedicated to the Bringer of Endless Night. It connects to Yithrilae in [[1915]].

author: Ray Colina
description: The waters here are often foggy.

author: Ray Colina
description: This swampy forest is often foggy. The Moths here can scream and drink blood like mosquitoes.

author: Zak Smith
description: The salt foam tumbles, slackens and slides down the grey, diffident faces of the slathered rocks.

author: Jason Sholtis
description: A loose confederation of mountain fools, even more degenerate than their cousins in [[1901]], install shabby rope bridges and ladders from peak to peak in this particularly craggy zone in a mad web. The broken bodies of countless unfortunate goofs litter the fjords.

author: Zak Smith
description: Victims of Lady Yakiva, [[1903]] Merchants headed for Orthrist [[1508]] and Eelvast [[1821]], bob lifelessly around the sinking ships and remains of their wares: d4 kinds of potions in spherical bottles of colored glass.

author: Trent B
description: 13 racist pirates drift aimlessly on a small but relatively fast vessel. They are recovering from a big night and seek healing magic. Or bacon.

author: Trent B
description: A ruined, black marble outpost lies beneath the waves. Conceals an entrance to the submerged caverns beneath.

author: Zak Smith
description: A drifting 15' diameter hollow copper sphere contains a 10' diameter egg, cushioned in velvet. Only the copper key from [[0924]] will open it. No magic can detect what kind of egg it is but it is definitely the egg of some kind of gestating creature and definitely worth a lot of money.

author: Joey Lindsey
description: The blue salamanders sought by Bored Queen Morgause [[1803]] gather here to feed on dead pirates (from [[1806]] and others).

author: Trent B
description: HOGS CROSSING (settlement) Humans and tall, goat-headed emaciates farm hogs/grain and moles/mushrooms respectively. Clerics of (primary human god) and Akerbeltz [[1021]] vie for religious dominance of the population. They tell stories of the lake god in [[2011]].

author: Ben Djarum
description: Hedge maze. At the center is the glass coffin of Caroulus of  Cymophane. If the glass is broken, Caroulus will rise up and attack as a 20 HD Lich.

author: Jason Sholtis
description: Rendezvous point for party of cutthroats, wizards and assassins from all corners of the Hexenbracken assembling to take down the witches to the west, starting with Yeegra in [[2009]]. Their plan involves sending off several sub-groups as diversions/cannon fodder to mitigate the witch's fearsome power.

author: Zak Smith
description: Horthrik Veil cannot be slain, and has grown wise in the ways of the Hexenbracken. However, he smells like an open wound [[0417]] and draws fierce creatures wherever he goes (roll wandering monsters x 3 ). He's spent eons in the bellies of the vilest beasts.

author: Ben Djarum
description: The great barbarian chieftain Marluk's long house is here with his tribe of 15 wereboar warriors.

author: Trent B
description: A deep, fabulously clean lake between mountain peaks. The men of Hogs Crossing [[2007]] say that at night, one of several terrible shapeless creatures will surface to commune with the moon. If somehow conversed with, it will share great detail of any one hex in the Hexenbracken and cause short term or permanent insanity to the listener.

author: Jason Sholtis
description: Stationary formations of sky-fungi send down continuous hail of relatively harmless spores in this otherwise desolate hex. Plants and animals within go about their business as normal even though covered in hideous fungal growths.

author: Zak Smith
description: Adventurers in an angular vessel with thick crystal windows are charged by Queen Jane of the City In The Waste with investigating the proliferation of insect cults in the southeast Hexenbracken ( [[0627]], [[0612]], [[0127]], [[0826]], [[0926]], [[0127]]). Unbeknownst to them all, they are secretly aided and overseen in their task is by the grotesque Toad Gods (Slaad), who can see through the eyes of any frog, frogling or toad in the world, including the vortex eyes of the blindheim [[1514]] .

author: Reece Carter
description: a pirate raiding ship, they have captured and blindfolded a pair of sea-witches, they are being used to conjure up winds and tides to help the pirates or hinder their foes. If being chased by the pirate vessel they are at +2 and you are at -2

author: Joey Lindsey
description: The water here is turbulent, but there is almost no wind or sea life. Swarms of bats from [[2115]] blacken the sky at dawn and dusk.

author: Claytonian JP
description: A  taurus-form, floating wizard/witch academy is located here. The high walls protect the students, and they catch their food each day in the middle.

author: Ben Djarum
description: A whirlpool forms beneath passing ships, transporting them to 1d4: 1- [[0723]] 2- [[1120]] 3- [[1620]] 4- [[1710]]

author: Reece Carter
description: this mash/swamp area has a glamor cast over it to make it still look like ocean, it has been put into place by a group of goblins who attack the ships that crash or get bogged here, they found a powerful wizards spellbook and this is the only spell they could work out (roll on wild magic table whenever a spell is cast in this area)

author: Trent B
description: 14 racist pirates in a small but relatively fast vessel. They want help capturing a magic laden vessel bound for the academy in 20 16. They know of the illusory goblinswamp in [[2018]].

author: Ben Djarum
description: The ruins of a sunken city rise up from the dark waters. Harpies and stirges live among the ruins, preying upon passing sailors.

author: Reece Carter
description: mountain of the gods. A single lonely mountain raises up out of the ocean and reaches high into the clouds, there are various paths along this mountain and they are all perilous to travel (they are designed to keep people out and gods in). A person in (random hex number) says they know a short cut and will be your sherper up the mountain (they are really a god, only clerics and paladins have a chance at noticing this, its like 01%)

author: Trent B
description: A well guarded merchant vessel with goods destined for the northern settlements of The Hexenbracken. Seeks information or help navigating the web of pirates and such.

author: Jason Sholtis
description: Verthram the Discommodious, sorcerer and dandy, lost an enchanted scarf made from the Worm God's own silk somewhere in this hex while zooming by on his magic carpet several days ago. He has charmed a gaggle of moon goblins to help him search and will suspect anyone he encounters of concealing his prized accessory.

author: Joey Lindsey
description: FNAM BAK, a peninsular ranch that raises oversized turtles, crabs, and black frogs that can be ridden, but are extremely picky and lethal. The top man is a retired adventurer who secretly has a map of the area tattooed on him that moves and changes, giving him an idea of local power struggles. He's wanted for murder in [[SEEKERSFILE]] [[0922]] and debts in [[GREASEGRAFT]] [[1210]].

author: Trent B
description: Ocean or river or whatever this is! With 5 dolphins!

author: Jack Mcnamee
description: The doldrums! Without wind, your boat is stuck.

author: Ben Djarum
description: On the bottom of this shallow patch of sea is a large round iron hatch. It can be opened by blowing the magical Horn of Trofalcomar, found hidden in the sunken city ruins in [[2020]]. The hatch leads to a lava tube that winds deep into a subterranean city of Beholders.

author: Zak Smith
description: The mist here is so thick that navigation is effectively random.

author: Joey Lindsey
description: A drowning bard and 7 sharks share this stretch of emerald green sea, a languid mist rising to mock his plight. He prays to the Gods of the Chrysanthemum Sea, but is finding no help.

author: Ben Djarum
description: The Floating Market of Lao-Shae. A bustling marketplace of sailors, traders, smugglers and pirates, built upon a series of large floating barges.

author: Reece Carter
description: a sweet little old lady and her small granddaughter are sitting trapped on some rocks. rescuing them will get you ambushed by some mer-people, leaving them their will cause your next D12 rolls to be at -2

author: Jason Sholtis
description: The center of the hex is the newly claimed domain of the ship-devouring Famished God, this time manifested as three conjoined blue whales with a colossal maw, seemingly filled with a starry night sky.

author: Joey Lindsey
description: a boat full of what appear to be dead Chaos Champions who lost a fight. In fact, they had a raging party last night and are all passed out; upon waking, they're hung over, sensitive, and heavily armed.

author: Jack Mcnamee
description: The darkness here is made of Shadow-men, which cover the entire island at night. If you touch them, you become a shadow-man.

author: Ray Colina
description: A pirate in a johnboat, he flees his irascible captain. On his back is tattooed the map to doorway in [[1402]].

author: Jack Mcnamee
description: New Providence; 30 lackadaisical pirates gather around buccan fires. Led by John Chandagnac, a fifth level thief.

author: Ben Djarum
description: On a grassy hill, a group of 12 sylphs gather beneath a full moon. If they discover that they are being watched, they will summon 10 wood elves riding upon stags to attack the intruders.

author: Zak Smith
description: Why do so many people in the Hexenbracken draw maps on things that aren't paper? Map thieves. Orbin Wayward in [[1608]] pays well.

author: M Nicksic
description: Salt flats where the Corvids race alchemical funny carts for bragging rights. They will take on outsiders too, but the stakes have to be much higher (usually a magic item wagered) for them to even bother.

author: Reece Carter
description: a large heard of bison/buffalo roam though this area, their skin can be hardened into a +1 suit of leather, their meat is delicious and works like a half cure light wounds (cures 1D4 HP), their horns are worth a lot of gold to the right people, and they are going extinct

author: Ray Colina
description: The volcanic rock hills here are much warmer than surrounding landscape. A network of lava tube caves lead to SURTUR THE FIRE GIANT CITY

author: Zak Smith
description: Sailing this way around the island at [[2114]]/[[2115]] is actually totally safe (other than a few spores from [[2012]]). A lot safer than sailing around [[2116]] anyway.

author: Jack Mcnamee
description: 10 elven savages, hunting swamp donkeys. Lead by a Rusk, a third level wolf.

author: Reece Carter
description: swamp donkeys live in this area, they are like normal donkeys but they have more moss and bracken growing off of my and stuck to them. they can be ridden and dont loose any speed though a swamp. you need to tame them first and they dont like elves

author: M Nicksic
description: Columnar basalt rises from the seabed to around water level, forming a bridge between [[2115]] and [[2216]]. Rough seas often hide this navigational hazard, which for some reason is not noted on any nautical charts.

author: Trent B
description: Eels. At dusk, the surface churns and writhes with eels.

author: Zak Smith
description: Goblin reavers riding drugged baboons leap hundreds of feet off the Bastard Isle onto ships when the weather forces them to pass close to the cliffs.

author: Chris Blauwkamp
description: Floating in the sea here is a barrel with three men. The baker and the candlemaker are pretty freaked out, but the butcher is trying to calm down the candlemaker with the offer of rendered fat from some eels from [[2117]].

author: Gus L
description: A pack of 2D6+2 flying monkey zouves armed with scimitars, armored fez's, scale mail and throwing axes.  The troop is forlornly staring across the water looking for a sign of a wizard to give their simian lives meaning.  Mostly they are simply a pack of scampering vandals who drop rocks on passing travelers.

author: Zak Smith
description: The far western edge of The Lesser Bastard has a tower in it full of eggs of all different species collected by someone insane.

author: Ben Djarum
description: Hidden in a rocky cove is a wild-eyed old man covered in seaweed. He sits in a tiny boat playing a flute for his long dead wife.

author: Reece Carter
description: a pirate ship that has no visible crew floats by. its actually crewed by ghost pirates, they will attack anyone that comes aboard their ship

author: Claytonian JP
description: Strange runed stones jut up here, forming a ring large enough for a small ship to enter. Anyone who prays here will find theirself, their companions, and their vessel on the top of a random mountain hex.

author: Reece Carter
description: a group of spider-goblins attack the party and attempt to herd them towards a pool of quicksand in the center of the hex. there are a number of magical items at the bottom of the pool of quicksand

author: Claytonian JP
description: 4 blue elves commune over a puddle of blood. This is a sacred matter, and they won't discuss the source of the blood with anyone willingly.

author: Ray Colina
description: Fishing boats frequent this bay. A wyvern from [[2127]], has on occasion swooped down to steal a catch as they pull up their nets. It has otherwise caused them no harm.

author: Joey Lindsey
description: the old man from [[2121]] wife is here, seeking passage west. She has been returned as a partially astral Paladin of the Beurocratic Demonities of Ashen Luck to claim the lives of witches; she will reward others who give her passage and promise to destroy witches a sword that, while pursuing that goal, has a +2 and Aura of Protection VS Magic (2/day, there's only one sword).

author: Reece Carter
description: this entire area is very shallow, you can tell this because of the various broken goblin flying machines that are in the water here, many a goblin died in their attempt to fly

author: Joey Lindsey
description: The surface here teems with Purple Garbugs; what appears to be a giant functioning circulatory system hundreds of miles beneath the waves is the red-robed Order of Forgotten Scars moving through their transparent underwater citadel. Large beasts swim around the outside, seeking a way in.

author: Reece Carter
description: a magical doorway is said to open here on the nights of the first equinox of summer. the doorway is open for exactly 3 bell tolls, but time travels differently where it opens into, a bell toll could be anywhere from one second to one year. where it opens to is different every time

author: Zak Smith
description: Island convent.

author: Zak Smith
description: Gutspasm Froth and his warband of seagoing chaos champions dedicated to the Famished God. Recently defeated those in [[2104]].

author: Jack Mcnamee
description: Insect pilgrims journeying to worship the Insect Queen in hex [[0127]].

author: Steve Sigety
description: The forest is riddled with tunnels. Movement near a tunnel opening has a 25% chance of drawing the attention of 2d8 serpent-man warriors and their chieftain, Acaxoatl the Hooded Venom-spitter.

author: Reece Carter
description: a troll war party is riding through here on large war pigs, they are hunting down some renagade warriors of chaos

author: Jensan Thuresson
description: An airship has crashed here. One strange survivor.

author: Zak Smith
description: Hooded Kenku (man sized Corvid) carrying a scythe, seeking sacrifices to the Demon of the Crossing In [[0521]]. If he finds a suitable victim he will call in rest of his murder.

author: Brian Green
description: A sizable church dedicated to the philosophy of Order is maintained by elderly paladins and priests.  They are physically frail but spiritually and magically powerful.  Will trade healing services and divine spellwork for information about chaos champions in the area.

author: Jensan Thuresson
description: Yellow apple tree valley. 1 in 6 apple contains polymorph juice.

author: Jack Mcnamee
description: Dead crones hang from withered trees.

author: Ray Colina
description: Witch’s Fog- A wandering cloud of shimmering fog, unless avoided, perfect shadow duplicates appear and attack when entered. They dissolve when killed or three rounds after leaving the mist.

author: Zak Smith
description: An colony of Aaracokra defend their nameless isle from the elven savages in [[2114]]. They carry chain weapons and worship dark gods.

author: Trent B
description: A trio of monks on a small Junk, destined for [[0902]] [[FELLMOUNT ABBEY]]. They have not heard from their companions and seek to ensure all is well. They have healing salves and medical skill for trade.

author: Trent B
description: SPIREWATER (Settlement) A quiet, well guarded Jetty town of humans. Farm rice and keep orchards in the fertile soil, trading fresh food to water-travelers. Try to maximise segregation from the unscrupulous [[MAW]] folk [[2219]], causing tensions to be high between the peoples.

author: Reece Carter
description: a large sinkhole in the ground that you cant see the bottom of, getting down it leads you to a random hex. The entire travel along the bottom of this sinkhole the pc's are chased by a bunch of different monsters from around the hex crawl that have fallen in there

author: Ray Colina
description: Asbjorn, a Bear Spirit and protector of bears, lives in a massive cave here. He can smell if you’ve ever killed a bear, and will not be pleased if you have.

author: Zak Smith
description: THE MAW (city) this is the largest settlement on The Bastard Isle, overlooking the curved harbor beneath. Favored by fugitives, philosophers and others who require both solitude and information.

author: Trent B
description: The bay of MAW [[2219]] contains a myriad of privately owned and leased boats, often used to provide seclusion and/or serenity for the meditations/treacheries/revelries of MAW folk. If a random boat is selected (D6): 1,2 - Unused, 3 - Philosophers/Sage 4- Shady Characters 5 - Carousing Humanoids 6 - Fishermen

author: Sam Mameli
description: The fighter and the blind thief wander this swamp. The fighter stands guard as the blind thief steals the eyes of sleeping adventurers.﻿

author: Reece Carter
description: a fight is happening between 22 mermaids and 22 goblin swimmers. The goblin swimmers are using a very primitive version of a SCUBA suit, many of them are drowning

author: Heikki Hallamaa
description: An old brass diving bell lies on the bottom, somewhat visible from the surface. Can accommodate 4 people. Worth 10.000 gp. Is haunted.﻿

author: Zak Smith
description: The horrible amphibious Fishwife of The Lesser Bastard lives in a slimy tower here, sending 5 seatrolls to seek husbands for her in the night.

author: Zak Smith
description: The ghoulish revenant of a drowned woman haunts this area. Hooked chains hang in her long black hair and she can control all the animals in the fen.

author: Jack Mcnamee
description: River. 5 carp.

author: Trent B
description: 3 Goat horned, Leech-Headed emaciates, 3 Leech-Headed Men and a Leech-Headed Halfling travelling north to THE [[MAW]] [[2219]]. They intend to drop a Leech Idol into the well to spread the Corruption of The Leeches [[1120]].

author: Zak Smith
description: Voxilla the Green, the two-headed war witch of the Lesser Bastard schemes in the sodden murk of a hidden temple dedicated to the great Carrion God. She is attended by leechfaces, vicious goblins of twenty tribes and borne aloft in a palanquin by her rhinocerous-horned half brothers.

author: Ben Djarum
description: Rakshasa wedding party aboard a sandalwood boat.

author: Zak Smith
description: Isle of Pale Worms. Lots of pale worms here.

author: Reece Carter
description: spined wurms are found in the various borrows around this area. They are a medium/large creature with 4-6HD (D8s), an AC of 15/7, 2 attacks each turn it attacks by rushing past a creature and cutting it with its many sharp spines Bite: 1D8 damage Rush past: 2D6 damage, fort(17)/con(-4)/save vs death or take 1D6 damage next turn Crush: 4D6 (same as above for a save, but damage is 2D6)

author: Zak Smith
description: Idiot barber with a shop here has a lonely line in hair cutting (he's crap), dentistry (not recommended) and surgery (decent). Insists its called the Isle of Whale Perms.

author: Reece Carter
description: poison worms (carrion crawlers) are found in this area. Just replace their paralysis ability with poison (1D6, save vs nausea, if failed you can only do half an action next turn, attempt save until one is passed) and they only get 1-2 attacks per turn

author: Zak Smith
description: The presumed-dead wife of the swordsman in [[1725]] is being taken forcibly to wed one of the ogre magi in [[1006]] she has taught a minah bird in this hex to repeat her message to him along with his location to anyone it meets.

author: Reece Carter
description: a airship is passing through here collecting the lightning that seems to be prevalent in this area. The airship is ran by a bunch of pirates (the good kind)

author: Zak Smith
description: Throb Castle--home to Cracklecut Throb, the Bloated Lord and his hideous court of Boschean sycophants.

author: Jack Mcnamee
description: Acres of deserted farmland.

author: Zak Smith
description: Vindisvein Monastery of the Borrowed Light. They make cheese and wine, illuminate holy books and charge travelers 3 cp to stay for the night.

author: Zak Smith
description: Careful observation of one of the mossy tidepools here reveals it is a precise miniature map of the entire Hexenbracken with tiny shaped rocks where the castles and buildings are. You'd have to know the area fairly well to recogize this and be very bored to notice the pool's even there.

author: Trent B
description: 3 Hunched, Bipedal Crabmen stalk the shallow waters for meats.

author: Ben Hannigan
description: A vast school of over 200 sharks patrol these waters.  All of them glow red in the moonlight.

author: Jack Mcnamee
description: Rotting corpses of 50 farmers. Fish from miles around have been feeding for days.

author: Ben Hannigan
description: A blue-steel rod of about two feet in diameter rises 1,000 feet out of the water, rotating with the wind.  It gives off occasional sparks of electricity at lower wind speeds, but will suddenly erupt into a steady aura of lightning stretching 200 feet from the rod if the winds achieve 100 mph or more.

author: Niles Calder
description: Shifting sandbanks threaten to ground passing ships.

author: Niles Calder
description: A convent of the secretive Sisters of the Good Burden is located here. They are powerful allies and dangerous foes for it is said that they can seduce a man with their voice alone, resist any poison and slay with a touch. They have long term goals that involve controlling the bloodlines of the world but to what end is unknown.

author: Ben Hannigan
description: A brackish pool of foul smelling water is here.  A drinker who fails their save vs. Poison will be transported to a landscape of flame and ash for 3d6 hours, taking one HP of fire damage for each hour there.

author: Zak Smith
description: A hunched man in the market here will sell you an ancient contract in an unknown language. It is a spiritually binding contract between the elves and the shark king and requires merely the signature of any single elf in order to go into effect: if signed, all sharks will obey the signing elf for one day each century.

author: Trent B
description: Orchids erupt gloriously from crevices in the mountainside. At night, 6 enigmatic wormpeople creep out of secret tunnels to tend their crop with fine silver tools (Worth 30gp/Worm). The orchids hold back a lurking rot, which would otherwise seep out of the deep mountains and corrupt surrounding hexes.

author: Reece Carter
description: the mountains have been carved into the shapes of various gods ans heros. Each carving is over the top of a cave entrance, but they are backwards, the good gods lead to bad places and the bad gods to good

author: Claytonian JP
description: A camp of lizard men are making a massive wooden sculpture of a king on a throne. It's base will have a magic door to [[0119]].

author: Jeff Rients
description: A pod of dolphins often play and fish in these waters.  Anyone belligerent to the pod will be reported to the Princess of the Drowned and the Damned.

author: Trent B
description: A swamp with pigs and mosquitoes. Vines harass every step.

author: David Brawley
description: A 10 headed hydra lives in these woods, and feasts on the pigs in [[2322]]. It's lair contains a portal into the depths of the dungeon in [[1402]].

author: M Nicksic
description: All the vines on the island seem to originate from an expanse of gigantic purple lotuses. The narcotic scent of their blossoms lures the unwary into a pond of digestive enzymes.

author: Wayne Snyder
description: A goblin fortress is perched on a rocky coast. A great sea beast menaces it from the depths.

author: Trent B
description: Petrified trees rise out of the waters here. A Swamp Hag, Brezelda The Fair, lives in a hut built among the treetops. She searches for her true love and/or eats people.

author: Reece Carter
description: a large floating fort made from various boats and ships (think water world) is here, its run by about 30-40 people, they will trade with you, you can also get hirelings/hench-people here. But if you mention anything about the fort in [[0325]] they will not trust you as they are their enemy

author: Darien Mason
description: all the things and creatures in parts of the descriptions that go over the mandated three sentence structure are metaphysically clipped and banished to this pocket dimension, which is quite crowded and please please please get me out of here I promise I'll never
